content: Obama said on National TV when first elected that he was not in the car manufacturing business and that he did not think bankrupcy was an option. A few days later Nancy tells the world that bankrupcy is not an option for chrysler and GM. Well, Monday GM joins Chrysler in going into bankrupcy. Now if it wasn't an option a few months ago why is it an option now? Where is Tim Geithner? Wasn't he picked by Barry to lead us out of the depression that Bush put us in? I'm telling you all this right now. If you all thought Bush was messed up an Obama and his side kicks are the answer then we are doomed as a nation.

content: I'll have to locate the article I read this morning.. The "NEW GM" will be owned by: Drum roll please... quote: The U.S. Treasury, which already has loaned GM $19.4 billion, would get 72.5 percent of the new company's stock and provide $30 billion in additional financing to keep the new GM operating under bankruptcy protection. Canada's government is expected to provide an additional $9 billion, a senior Obama administration official said. A United Auto Workers trust that will take over retiree health care expenses will get 17.5 percent, and the old GM, effectively owned by the bondholders, would get a 10 percent stake. GM's existing shareholders will probably lose everything. "It's fair to say that there would be little to no recovery," an administration official said. "http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/ap/nation/article_f48dafbc-52c2-553b-a892-5a10cf76ce9c.html"

GM's existing shareholders will probably lose everything. "It's fair to say that there would be little to no recovery," an administration official said.

content: Leave now...with all this drama in American politics to leave is to pass up on a unique opportunity to live trough one of the worst series of elections in the history of the country starting about twenty years ago... We have lost touch with the knack to move our government by democratic principles we were founded on and lack the initiative to tar a feather the lobbyists (and elected officials) and foriegn influence that has train wrecked our system... Time to see it through and make sure the grandkids have a nation to be proud of. Any thoughts as to when we start and where?

content: It is going to be up to the Veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan war to stand up and protest what is going on in our country. They are fighting for our safety and for freedom of others. While they are off fighting, some on their 5th deployment, our freedoms are being taken away from us by the same people who swore an oath to protect them. Once the current Veterans take a stand and simply say they are fed up then and only then will I stand next to them and sling arms.

Auto Industry Collapse Is Not an Option, Obama Says Article Comments (5) MORE IN POLITICS » EmailPrinter FriendlyShare: Yahoo Buzz ↓ More Save This ↓ More Text By CHRISTOPHER CONKEY President-elect Barack Obama suggested that bankruptcy wasn't a good option for Detroit's Big Three automakers, saying "these aren't ordinary times" given the country's current economic problems. "The Big Three automakers have made repeated strategic mistakes," Mr. Obama said. "But what I've also said is that the auto industry is the backbone of American manufacturing. … I don't think it's an option to simply allow it to collapse." Does this help a little? I get so tired of doing other people's homework at times. People on Mil.Com who know me Know that I tell the truth 87% of the time.

content: Hi ProudformerMarine; I have been to Costa Rica and although nice it can be expensive to live there. The city of David in Panama is not too far from Costa Rica and I could drive across the boarder within an hour. Panama allows retirees many benefits such as no home owners taxes for the first 20 years. No income taxes, 50% off hotel rooms during the week, 30% discount on food bought in restaurants. Discounts on prescriptions, a good VA medical clinic. Some great 5 star restaurants and beer cost $0.43 a bottle! The $400.00 a month I pay in taxes here in the US could go for a full time maid/cook and Gardner in Panama. When I was stationed in Panama back in 1981, I fell in love with the ocean, jungle, and the little road side bars that I stopped at to get a bite to eat and a cold one. Sure things have changed but some have not. I'm just hanging on till the wife retires from Civil Service. My remains will still be scattered over the out field at Yankee Stadium when I die.

Discounts on prescriptions, a good VA medical clinic. Some great 5 star restaurants and beer cost $0.43 a bottle! The $400.00 a month I pay in taxes here in the US could go for a full time maid/cook and Gardner in Panama. When I was stationed in Panama back in 1981, I fell in love with the ocean, jungle, and the little road side bars that I stopped at to get a bite to eat and a cold one. Sure things have changed but some have not. I'm just hanging on till the wife retires from Civil Service. My remains will still be scattered over the out field at Yankee Stadium when I die.
title: Obama and Pelosi are lacking in the intelligence dept.

content: Yankee Stadium? Duster your in deep trouble... what happens when they re-sod

content: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: Hi ProudformerMarine; I have been to Costa Rica and although nice it can be expensive to live there. The city of David in Panama is not too far from Costa Rica and I could drive across the boarder within an hour. Panama allows retirees many benefits such as no home owners taxes for the first 20 years. No income taxes, 50% off hotel rooms during the week, 30% discount on food bought in restaurants. Discounts on prescriptions, a good VA medical clinic. Some great 5 star restaurants and beer cost $0.43 a bottle! The $400.00 a month I pay in taxes here in the US could go for a full time maid/cook and Gardner in Panama. When I was stationed in Panama back in 1981, I fell in love with the ocean, jungle, and the little road side bars that I stopped at to get a bite to eat and a cold one. Sure things have changed but some have not. I'm just hanging on till the wife retires from Civil Service. My remains will still be scattered over the out field at Yankee Stadium when I die. Roger That Duster! I was with C/4-20th (M) Infantry at Fort Clayton from AUG80 to end of JUN82. I've been eyeing a little piece of heaven 45 minutes drive out of Panana City and 15 minutes inland from Pacific Ocean... Everything you've mentioned above is "spot on!" Eh..., except the Yankee Stadium bit...

content: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by WepsFP: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: Obama said on National TV when first elected that he was not in the car manufacturing business and that he did not think bankrupcy was an option. A few days later Nancy tells the world that bankrupcy is not an option for chrysler and GM. Well, Monday GM joins Chrysler in going into bankrupcy. Now if it wasn't an option a few months ago why is it an option now? Where is Tim Geithner? Wasn't he picked by Barry to lead us out of the depression that Bush put us in? I'm telling you all this right now. If you all thought Bush was messed up an Obama and his side kicks are the answer then we are doomed as a nation. Could you provide the quote that Obama said bankruptcy was "not an option"? Second paragraph. For anyone who was listening in January, February and March of this year bankruptcy was clearly not the favored option of the administration. "http://www.timesdispatch.com/rtd/business/companies/article/obama_bankruptcy_filing_new_lease_on_life_for_chrysler/264735/" So what your saying is, it was always an option. I thought so. Perhaps Duster has the quote where Obama stated it wasn't an option.
